	Subpart D - Program 3 Prevention Program includes the requirements of the OHSA PSM standard; therefore, detailed RMP Prevention Program documentation is not included with this Offsite Consequence Analysis Report. RMP Program 3 Prevention Program information is maintained with the OSHA PSM documentation.

1.0 	ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM-BACKGROUND
The Accidental Release Prevention (ARP) requirements mandated in Section 112 (r) of the 1990 Clean Air Act (CAA) Amendments were promulgated by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) on June 20, 1996. The requirements are codified in 40 CFR 68, Subparts A  H. Under the ARP Program, a Stationary Source that has more than a threshold quantity of a regulated substance in a process must comply with the requirements of the ARP provisions.
The List Rule (under 40 CFR 68, Subpart C, and Tables 1 through 4 of 68.130) identifies regulated substance threshold quantities for determining ARP Program applicability. Threshold quantities have been established for flammable and toxic substances. The threshold quantity for all regulated flammables (Table 3 of the regulation) is 10,000 pounds. The threshold determination for mixtures of flammable substances is in accordance with 40 CFR 68.115(b) (2). In cases where the listed substance is greater than one percent by weight o

f the mixture (for a flammable), the entire weight of the mixture is considered in the threshold determination, unless it can be demonstrated that the mixture itself does not have a National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) flammability hazard rating of 4. The threshold quantity for regulated toxic substances listed on Table 1 of the regulation varies according to each substance and ranges from 500  20,000 pounds.
Each covered process regulated under the ARP Program is assigned as either a Program 1, 2, or 3 status and must meet the applicable criteria of the assigned program. Program 1 processes are those that meet the following criteria:
·	the process has not had an accidental release in the past five years that resulted in an offsite consequence (i.e., injuries, deaths, or environmental damage);
·	the distance to an endpoint is less than the distance to any public receptor; and
·	Emergency response has been coordinated with local emergency response organizations.

Program 3 processes meet the following criteria:
·	the distance to an endpoint exceeds the distance to any public receptor; or
·	the process has had an accidental release in the past five years resulting in an offsite consequence; and either.
·	Falls into one of ten NAICS codes [32211, 31411, 32511, 325181, 325188, 325192, 325199, 325211, 325311, and 32532]; or subject to the OSHA process safety management standard [40 CFR 68.10 (d) (2)].

Program 2 processes are those that do not meet Program 1 or 3 criteria.
2.0		Stationary Source ARP Program Status Determination
	2.1.	Background
Energy Transfer Gulf Coast Operations is the owner/operator of the Stationary Source, LPG Storage Facility, located at a latitude 31° 22' 23.92" N and longitude 89° 16' 2.47" W in Forrest County, Texas. 

The Hattiesburg LPG Storage Facility is designed to store butane during off-peak months. It uses both aboveground storage tank facilities consisting of one 97,610-gallon butane pressurized storage tank and four 31,140-gal

lon butane pressurized storage tanks. The primary function of the aboveground storage tank are for to/from storage transfer between railcar and underground storage cavern.  (The worst-case scenario for salt domes would be examined in a manner similar to that for underground storage tanks. Reservoirs or vessels sufficiently buried underground are passively mitigated or prevented from failing catastrophically. You should evaluate the failure of piping connected to underground storage for the worst-case and alternative scenarios. From Search EPA.gov questions/answers updated May 30, 2023).

By virtue of the flammable effects associated with NGLs, it is necessary to observe certain safety precautions to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to employee health, and to minimize the threat and impact to nearby members of the community. 

2.2		Hazard Assessment
The Stationary Source was evaluated to determine if any regulated flammable or toxic substances were present in the process and if they exceeded the threshold quantity. All equipment and vessels are connected and/or co-located; consequently, for the purposes of the ARP Program, all equipment and vessels are part of multiple processes. The identification of even a single vessel exceeding threshold quantities of a regulated flammable or toxic substance would subject a process to threshold determination for offsite consequence analysis.
There are no regulated toxic substances at this Stationary Source more than RMP threshold quantities.
This Stationary Source does store regulated flammable substances in vessels that exceed threshold quantity; therefore, the Stationary Source is a covered process with regulated substances subject to threshold determination for offsite consequence analysis (see Table 1). A brief description of the regulated flammable substances identified and evaluated at the Stationary Source is presented as follows.

2.2.1    Regulated Flammable Substances

The RMP regulated substances handled at the Stationary Source is Refinery Grade Butane (RGB).

2.2.2    Regulated Toxic Substances

No toxic chemicals on the List Rule are used at the Stationary Source.

3.0	OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS-BACKGROUND
Under the accidental release provisions of the CAA, regulated sources with covered processes are required to complete an offsite consequence analysis, including a worst-case release analysis. Regulated sources with covered processes in Programs 2 and 3 are required to conduct alternative release analyses as well. The worst-case consequence analysis and the analysis for alternative scenarios are to be reported in the Risk Management Plan (RMP).

3.1	Worst-Case Scenario (WCS)
The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has defined a worst-case release as the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a vessel or process line failure that results in the greatest distance to a specified endpoint. A WCS analysis is required for each toxic substance in a covered process while only one WCS analysis is required fo

r regulated flammable substances as a class. WCSs are assumed to occur at ground level with meteorological conditions defined as atmospheric stability class F (stable atmosphere), wind speed of 1.5 meter per second (3.4 miles per hour), and an ambient air temperature of 25oC (77oF). Topography for WCSs is either rural or urban depending on site location.
The basis for determining the WCS for flammable liquids are as follows:


(1)	For regulated flammable substances that are normally liquids at ambient temperature, the owner or operator shall assume that the entire quantity in the vessel or pipe, is spilled instantaneously to form a liquid pool. 
For liquids at temperatures below their atmospheric boiling point, the owner or operator shall assume that the entire quantity in the vessel or pipe, is spilled instantaneously to form a liquid pool.

(2)	The owner or operator shall assume that the quantity which becomes vapor in the first 10 minutes is involved in the vapor cloud explosion.
Factors in selecting a worst-case scenario. 

(1)	Smaller quantities handled at higher process temperature or pressure; 

(2)	Proximity to the boundary of the stationary source. 

(3)	Worst-case scenario methodologies are illustrated in Worst Case Scenario Modeling Assumptions considered, extent of 1 PSIG and Receptors.
Flammable Substances
Regulated flammable substances or mixtures containing flammable substances include both gas and volatile liquids (flash point below 73oF, boiling point below 100oF). The WCS assumes that the total quantity of a vapor cloud is released and detonates. The endpoint for a WCS involving a regulated flammable substance or mixture is an over pressure of 1 pound per square inch (psi). For a regulated flammable substance, consequence distance determination is based on its heat of combustion. For regulated flammable mixtures, the component with the highest heat of combustion can be used for consequence distance determination or, if preferred, directly calcul

ated using RMP Comp calculator on the EPA website. The quantity of a regulated substance/mixture used to determine distance to endpoint is the largest quantity of a regulated substance/mixture in a single vessel.

3.1.1	Stationary Source Worst-Case Scenario for Regulated Flammables
The Stationary Source can store NFPA 4 Regulated Liquids in multiple vessels inside the boundary.
It was determined that the 97,610 gallons/469,510. (worst case assumption of 100% full) of Flammable Mixture stored in T-4225 Storage Tank (T-4225 Storage Tank is modeled as Scenario 1 in modeling calculations).  would be the Stationary Sources worst case scenario for flammable liquids due to the number of receptors reached by this vessel. (Weight of flammables are based on a specific gravity of 0.5800 (Water = 1) for a pound per gallon. Flammable Mixture (4.738 Lbs./Gal.).

3.1.2	Stationary Source Worst Case Scenario for Regulated Toxics

The Stationary Source does not have any toxic substances held above the threshold quantity. Analysis of one worst-case release scenario for all regulated toxic substances is therefore, not required.

3.2      Alternative Release Scenario (ARS)

An ARS describes an incident that is more likely to occur than those cited for a WCS. One ARS analysis is required for each listed toxic substance in a covered process that exceeds threshold quantity while only one ARS analysis is required for all flammable substances as a class. For ARSs, both active and passive mitigation systems can be considered, however for this study no mitigation was used.
Alternative release scenarios for flammable substances should have the potential to cause substantial damage, including on-site damage. Alternative release scenarios for toxic substances should be those that lead to concen

trations above the toxic endpoint beyond the process fence line. Those releases that have the potential to reach the public are of the greatest concern.

3.2.1    Stationary Source Alternative Release Scenario for Regulated Flammables

Five (5) separate alternative release scenarios were modeled for various quadrants of the Stationary Source and differing volumes. These scenarios were also modeled per the requirements of Subpart B §68.28 (b) (2).
It was determined that a release from a ruptured seal of the swivel joint of loading arm at 1,810 pound per minute rate would be the primary alternative release scenario. Using RMP*Comp it was determined that a release of this amount of liquid would result in a vapor cloud fire with an endpoint (1 PSI) distance of 0.10 miles. The distance to the ARS endpoint for the flammable mixture is presented in Table 3. Modeling calculations show distances to endpoint calculations.

TABLE 3

Stationary Source Alternative Release Scenario for Regulated Toxics
The Stationary Source does not have any toxic substances held above the threshold quantity. Analysis of each regulated toxic substance is, therefore, not required.

3.3	Off Site Impacts

The ARP regulations require that public and environmental receptors be determined within the worst-case scenario area. In addition to residential population, the presence of institutions, parks, and commercial and industrial buildings are to be identified. Table 4 shows the number of public receptors for the worst-case and alternative-case release scenario based on ground-level inventory of receptors. Table 5 is based on MARPLOT map verification and shows the n

umber of environmental receptors.

4.0	ACCIDENT HISTORY

According to 40 CFR 68.42, The owner or operator shall include in the five-year accident. 
history all accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.
The Stationary Source has not had any accidental releases during the past five years that meet the criteria for an accidental release as discussed in 40 CFR 68.42.

5.0	VERIFICATION OF PROCESS INFORMATION

Facilities have an ongoing responsibility to monitor whether changes to any process or to the quantities stored or handled alter the Stationary Sources program level eligibility. A 5-year renewal also gives the Stationary Source personnel the opportunity to verify that each covered process still meets the eligibility criteria for

its program level. Based on information regarding the type and quantity of stored/handled chemicals currently onsite, it was verified that the Stationary Source process areas are Program 3 processes under the ARP Program (40 CFR 68).

6.0 	REVIEW OF EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The Stationary Source is not designated as a first responder in case of an accidental release of a regulated substance. The Stationary Source maintains a written emergency response program, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidently released. If Stationary Source employees take part in responding to accidental releases, then the Stationary Source is required to periodically review and update, as appropriate, the Stationary Sources emergency response program and notify employees of any changes to the emergency response plan (40 CFR 68.95). Updates should include the date of the most recent review of the emergency response program and most recent training. The Stationary Source is also expected to contact the Local Emergency Planning Committee to verify whether the Stationary Source is currently included in the community emergency response plan. Section 9 of the CDX RMP Submit Document (Appendix 4) provides updated information (including dates and other pertinent details) that was reviewed by the Stationary Source to ensure that the procedures for the emergency response program have been updated and verified.

7.0	GENERAL DUTY CLAUSE
Owners and operators of facilities have a general duty to identify hazards that may result from accidental releases of any flammable or toxic substance at the Stationary Source. In addition, owners and operators are required to design and maintain a safe Stationary Source and minimize the consequences of any releases of these substances that occur.

As shown below, the Stationary Source has identified substances at the Stationary Source regulated under the General Duty Clause. These substances, their location, potential hazards, accident prevention measures, and consequence minimization measures are included in Appendix 1. The following substances are addressed under General Duty: Butane (C4) 106-97-8

MODELING ASSUMPTIONS 
(All calculations were performed on RMP Comp July 20, 2021 @ https://cdxnodengn.epa.gov/cdx-rmp-maintain/action/rmp-comp)
Quantity. 	
EPA has defined (§68.3) a worst-case release as the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a vessel or process line (pipe) failure that results in the greatest distance to a specified endpoint. For substances in vessels, you must assume release of the largest amount in a single vessel; for substances in pipes, you must assume release of the largest amount in a pipe. The largest quantity should be determined considering administrative controls. Administrative controls are written procedures that limit the quantity of a substance that can be stored or processed in a vessel or pipe at any one time, or, alternatively, occasionally allow a vessel or pipe to store larger than usual quantities (e.g., during turnaround). You do not need to consider the possible causes of the worst-case release or the probability that such a release might occur; the release is simply assumed to take place. 
Release Height.
 All releases are assumed to take place at ground level for the worst-case analysis. This is a conservative assumption in most cases. Even if you think a ground-level release is unlikely at your site, you must use this assumption for the worst-case analysis. 
Wind Speed and Atmospheric Stability. 
Meteorological conditions for the worst-case scenario are defined in the rule as atmospheric stability class F (stable atmosphere) and wind speed of 1.5 meters per second (3.4 miles per hour). If, however, you can demonstrate that the minimum wind spe

ed at your site (measured at 10 meters) has been higher than 1.5 meters per second, or that the maximum atmosphere stability has always been less stable than class F, you may use the minimum wind speed and most stable atmospheric conditions at your site for the worst-case analysis. To demonstrate higher minimum wind speeds or less stable atmospheric conditions, you will need to document local meteorological data from Chapter 4, 4-7 Offsite Consequence Analysis the previous three years that are applicable to your site. If you do not keep weather data for your site (most sources do not), you may call another nearby source, such as an airport, or a compiler, such as the National Weather Service, to determine wind speeds for your area. 

Exhibit 3-1 in Chapter 3 describes atmospheric stability classes in relation to wind speed and cloud cover. Your airport or other source will be able to give you information on cloud cover. A small difference in wind speed probably will not lead to a significant decrease in the distance to the endpoint.

APPENDIX A
GENERAL DUTY CLAUSE
The Accident Release Prevention/Risk Management Program (ARP/RMP) regulation includes a statement that all sites must comply with the general duty clause of the Clean Air Act (CAA) Section 112(r) (1) [see attached]. The general duty clause provides that owners and operators have a general duty to identify hazards that may result from accidental releases, design, and maintain a safe Stationary Source, and minimize the consequences of any releases that occur. The general duty clause affects all substances considered to be hazardous, not just those flammable and toxic materials listed in the ARP/RMP regulation. Therefore, Kinder Morgan LP has developed a General Duty Form to assure compliance with the general duty clause of the CAA as referenced in the ARP/RMP regulation.

Prevention of Accidental Release
Background
The Chemical Accidental Release Prevention Provisions are contained in 40 CFR Part 68. The reg

ulation establishes requirements for a stationary source that has more than the threshold quantity of a listed flammable or toxic substance in a process or storage. Sources having less than the threshold quantity of a listed substance, or any quantity of a non-listed, extremely hazardous substance, are subject to the general duty requirements of the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990. The June 20, 1996, edition of the Federal Register states the following on page 31670.
...The general duty clause provides that owners and operators have a general duty to identify hazards that may result from accidental releases, design, and maintain a safe Stationary Source, and minimize the consequences of any releases that occur. The general duty clause is a self-executing statutory requirement: it requires no regulations or other EPA action to take effect. The clause provides a separate statutory mechanism that EPA will use in appropriate circumstances to ensure the protection of public health and the environment.

Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990
112 (r) (1)	Prevention of Accidental Releases-
Purpose and General Duty  It shall be the objective of the regulations and programs authorized under this subsection to prevent the accidental release and to minimize the consequences of any such release of any substance listed pursuant to paragraph (3)  (listed chemicals)  or any other extremely hazardous substance. The owners and operators of stationary sources producing, processing, handling, or storing such substances have a general duty...to identify hazards which may result from such releases using appropriate hazard assessment techniques, to design and maintain a safe Stationary Source taking such steps as are necessary to prevent releases, and to minimize the consequences of accidental releases which do occur...
Implementation
The substance regulated under the general duty clause at the Stationary Source listed on the attached form. Potential hazards, accident prevention measure

s, and consequence minimization measures following accidental releases will be reviewed as needed.

Accident Prevention Measures
The Accidental Release Prevention Program Executive Summary included in the Risk Management Plan describes the management system in place to ensure safe operation of gas Stationary Source processes. The following summarizes the existing safety features which are detailed in the Risk Management Plan.
	The Stationary Source encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention.
	The Stationary Source keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes.
	The Stationary Source has procedures in place to ensure that contractors perform their work in a safe manner, have the appropriate knowledge and skills, are aware of the hazards of their workplace, understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, understand, and follow site safety rules, and inform Stationary Source personnel of any hazards that they find during their work.
	The Stationary Source has well-established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition.
	The Stationary Source promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident.

Consequence Mitigation Measures
The following is a description of existing safety features applicable to reduce the consequences of (mitigate) accidental releases of regulated substances at the Stationary Source. These safety features include: (1) fire suppression and extinguishing equipment, and (2) personal protective equipment.
The safety features, i

nstalled on many units to help contain/control a release or quickly detect a release include: (1) process relief valves, (2) isolation valves (manual or automated), (3) curbing or diking to contain liquid releases, and (4) atmospheric relief devices.
